• Frame 1 & Frame 2:  
  – The road begins curving gently to the left toward a major intersection with multiple lanes.  
  – Signs are a bit distant but you can see at least two signal heads over the intersection (one for left‐turn arrows, one for through lanes).

2) Contextual Reasoning

Because the ego driver must make a left turn at this intersection and then “immediately” make a right turn afterward, the most sensible choice is to pick the right‐most lane that still allows a left turn. That reduces the need for sudden lane changes in the intersection’s cross street.

3) Match to Answer Choices

• Lane 1 (far left) would leave the vehicle in the left‐most position on the cross street, complicating a quick right turn.  
• Lane 2 is also a left‐turn lane but is farther to the right, making it easier to set up the subsequent right turn.  
• Lanes 3 and 4 appear to be through (and possibly right‐turn) lanes at this intersection, so you cannot turn left from those.  

4) Provide the Best Answer

Lane 2 is the right‐most lane that permits a left turn, which best enables an immediate right turn afterward.
